SENT.plain: Patients with antiphospholipid syndrome are characterized by the association of thrombosis or pregnancy morbidity and the presence of antiphospholipid autoantibodies

Particularly, anti-beta(2)-glycoprotein (beta(2) GPI) autoantibodies correlate with thrombosis, suggesting an antibody-induced gain of prothrombotic function and/or an antibody-induced loss of antithrombotic function of beta(2) GPI
In the search for potential antithrombotic properties of beta(2) GPI, we found that beta(2) GPI inhibits von Willebrand factor (VWF)-induced platelet aggregation
In addition, platelet adhesion to a VWF-coated surface was decreased by 50% in the presence of beta(2) GPI (P < .03)
beta(2) GPI binds to the A1 domain of VWF but preferably when the A1 domain is in its active glycoprotein Ibalpha-binding conformation
Anti-beta(2) GPI antibodies isolated from a subset of antiphospholipid syndrome patients neutralized the beta(2) GPI-VWF interactions and thus the inhibitory activity of beta(2) GPI
In comparison to healthy individuals, the amounts of active VWF in circulation were increased 1.5-fold (P < .001) in patients positive for lupus anticoagulant (LAC) due to anti-beta(2) GPI antibodies
Thus, beta(2) GPI is a biologically relevant inhibitor of VWF function by interfering with VWF-dependent platelet adhesion
Anti-beta(2) GPI autoantibodies neutralize this inhibitory function and are associated with increased levels of active VWF
This mode of action could contribute to the thrombosis and consumptive thrombocytopenia observed in patients with anti-beta(2) GPI antibodies
